I came to Congress to lower costs for our families, create jobs, ensure every Marylander has access to health care, and support strong small businesses – not pad my own financial portfolio. That’s why I’ve co-sponsored @Rep_Magaziner and @RepChipRoy’s bipartisan Restore Trust in Congress Act to ban Members of Congress and their families from owning and profiting off of individual stocks.

While passing this bill won’t solve every problem in Washington, it will send a powerful message: your representatives work for you, and you alone. It’s time we prove it.

Thank you to the Anne Arundel County Public Library team, trustees, and Foundation Board for organizing the incredible ‘For the Love of the Library’ event! I’m so grateful I could join over 400 fellow library lovers to continue supporting the amazing work of our Anne Arundel County Public libraries to educate, enrich, and inspire our community 📖

Happy Jewish New Year! Rosh Hashanah symbolizes a time for self-reflection and renewal from the year past, as well as a moment of hope for the year ahead. For all those who celebrate, I hope this is the start of a sweet and fruitful new year. Shana Tovah! https://t.co/OV1qvK7o6N

As we navigate these uncertain and sometimes even dark times, we have to focus on what’s giving us hope for the future of our country. Leaning in, participating, and advocating is making a difference – whether that’s attending a town hall, pushing for litigation, or fighting to open doors to agencies – and seeing how you all make a difference gives me hope. But we must keep communicating, keep coming together and having tough conversations – especially as Members of Congress – to turn the page and overcome these difficult times.

Since 1983, the Chesapeake Bay Program partnership has convened states across the Watershed to shape voluntary policy agreements which guide state and regional action to restore the health of the Chesapeake Bay Watershed with clear goals and measurable outcomes. But the current Chesapeake Bay agreement – signed in 2014 – has a deadline of December 2025 for many of its goals and initiatives. That’s why I’ve joined @RepStenyHoyer, @ChrisVanHollen, and 21 other bipartisan Members of Congress in calling for a new Chesapeake Bay agreement that will combat pollution, protect our native fish and wildlife from invasive species, improve water quality, and more to ensure a healthy Bay for generations to come.

More than 8,800 civilian firefighters support our servicemembers at military installations across the DoD, responding to structural fires, aircraft emergencies, hazardous materials incidents, and more – yet recent reports indicate that the military service plans to eliminate vacant firefighter positions, limit the use of overtime, and interpret requirements in a manner that could lead to station closures. I joined @RepJenKiggans in demanding the secretaries of the Army, the Navy, and the Air Force address these staffing gaps for emergency services that keep our servicemembers safe and maintain our overall military readiness.

Currently, nearly 73% of American workers do not have access to paid leave even in cases of serious personal health issues, in times of safety concerns, or when dealing with military deployment. Hardworking Americans should not be forced to choose between their family, their health, or their safety and their jobs. That’s why I’ve co-sponsored @rosadelauro and @SenGillibrand’s FAMILY Act to ensure every worker has access to comprehensive paid family and medical leave our workforce has earned and deserves.

50 years ago, Title IX opened the doors for women in athletics, but today we are still fighting for fair treatment and fair pay. In other professional sports, players receive around 50% of revenue from TV deals, tickets, sponsorships, and merchandise sales – WNBA players receive 0% of that revenue even though the value of the WNBA has more than doubled. I’ve joined my @DemWomenCaucus colleagues to urge the WNBA to fairly negotiate with their players on contracts that reflect their hard work.

In the wake of the Sandy Hook tragedy in 2012, Shannon Watts rallied concerned moms across the nation to advocate for legislation and better safety measures to prevent tragedies like these from happening again. Today, @MomsDemand has more than 11 million members across the nation, and they’ve been at the forefront of fighting for reforms even in our darkest moments – including when our local Anne Arundel County chapter fought for common-sense gun safety legislation in the wake of the Capital Gazette attack. In our current moment, their work is more crucial than ever – I’m incredibly grateful they could come out to Washington for a tour and a chance to discuss how I can uplift their efforts in Congress.

In 2010, President Obama repealed Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell, ending the discriminatory policy that prevented servicemembers from being openly LGBTQ+ without threat of being discharged. 14 years ago today, the repeal was fully implemented for that harmful policy across all branches of the U.S. military, but not before thousands of brave servicemembers were discharged for who they were. As a member of the House Armed Services Committee and @EqualityCaucus, I’m committed to fighting for the rights of those who selflessly serve our country.

Yet, the Trump Administration has issued new guidelines that would require prescriptions for anyone under 65 trying to get the COVID vaccine  – including high risk individuals – and to not recommend the Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR) vaccine for children under 4, ignoring decades of scientific evidence. Maryland is committed to protecting vaccine access for Marylanders of all ages during these uncertain times by keeping flu and COVID vaccinations available without prescriptions and continuing insurance coverage for recommended vaccines. Today is National POW/MIA Recognition Day, a time to honor those who were held captive and those who are still missing in service of our country – many of whom were not given a proper chance to be laid to rest. Over 1,200 Marylanders who served in World War I, World War II, Korea, and Vietnam are considered “missing in action,” presumed dead. Today and everyday, we commemorate those lives lost and uplift their families who never received closure for their loved ones who made the ultimate sacrifice for our nation.

Today, I voted yes on H.Res.719 – a resolution condemning the assassination of Charlie Kirk and all forms of political violence. I did so not because I agreed with Mr. Kirk or shared his worldview, but because I swore an oath to uphold and defend a Constitution that guarantees our ability as Americans to have free and open debate without fear of violent repercussions. Please see below for my full statement on political violence and where we go from here.

Our country is on the precipice of a health care crisis. House Democrats have made clear for weeks that we are ready to negotiate a bipartisan continuing resolution that helps working people, lowers costs, and protects Americans’ health care. But instead of engaging in good-faith negotiations, Republicans who control the House, Senate, and the Executive Branch have pushed forward a partisan funding bill that will place no checks on the President’s powers and will continue to rip away health care from Marylanders. I voted NO.

The Eastport Civic Association is a volunteer-led organization that has dedicated years to improving the quality of life for residents of Eastport from Spa Creek to Back Creek and every neighborhood in between. I’m so grateful that I could make it back from D.C. (and over Spa Creek) to join their annual picnic – a great excuse to enjoy some local barbecue, catch up with friends, and thank the first responders who keep our neighbors safe everyday. In July, I joined over 90 of my Democratic colleagues in calling on the Court of Appeals to stop the unlawful agreement between the IRS and ICE, giving immigration enforcement agents access to millions of taxpayers’ confidential records. Just this week, the court ruled to restrict data sharing between the two agencies, upholding not only our constitutional powers, but the longstanding bipartisan intent to keep a strict firewall between immigration enforcement and tax administration. Let this be a reminder to lean in and fight for the right to privacy everyone in our country deserves.

For over 15 years, Chesapeake Conservancy has worked tirelessly on land conservation and watershed restoration efforts to improve the health of our Chesapeake Bay - and they’ve been my partner in adding the strongest data to build the strongest policy possible. Thank you to the Conservancy’s Board of Directors for inviting me to give updates about my work to protect the Bay in Congress and discuss ways we can strengthen the Chesapeake National Recreation Area, improve data collection and technology for conservation, and continue collaborating to uplift their amazing efforts as part of the House Natural Resources Committee.

Political divisions are at a boiling point in this country. Our nation was founded on the values of free speech and democracy –  encouraging disagreement and accountability through our voices and our vote rather than through violence. Now more than ever we should remember those values and find what collectively unites in Congress, in our communities, and across our country rather than what divides us.

In 1786, our Founders met right here in Annapolis and decided our nation needed a new system of government to form a more perfect Union. After over a year of debate and compromises, they signed one of the most influential documents in American history in Philadelphia: the U.S. Constitution. For the past 238 years, the Constitution has upheld our most fundamental rights and values, guiding our government through checks and balances during some of our darkest moments in history. That’s why I’ve joined @RepBonnie and @Robert_Aderholt’s resolution to make today Constitution Day.

The Department of Defense covers millions of acres of natural habitats on its bases – habitats that are used by our military to train in realistic environments. Exempting the DoD from compliance with the Endangered Species Act would remove our military’s unique advantage to navigate these realistic environments, harming our military readiness. That’s why, as Vice Ranking Member of the House of Natural Resources, I spoke against this NDAA amendment, and ultimately, I’m grateful my colleagues came together in a bipartisan manner to ensure this language was not included in the final version of the annual defense bill.

PS This was my first time “managing” time on the House floor - meaning I controlled and allocated time on debate of the amendment.

”That our flag was still there”

211 years ago today, Francis Scott Key immortalized the moment when our country won a hard-fought battle with the British and our flag remained flying  over Baltimore’s own Fort McHenry in his poem “The Star-Spangled Banner.” For the past 94 years, that poem has been our national anthem, reminding us not only of our perseverance and resilience as a nation but of the values that have shaped our country – freedom and bravery to fight for liberty and justice for all.

In 2001, Janice Hayes Williams rode shotgun with her Uncle George to visit the Crownsville Hospital Patient Cemetery for the first time – what she saw devastated her. On the gravestones where there should have been names, dates, or any dedication to someone’s life, there were only numbers. Last week, for the first time, more than 1,700 patients – many of whom died from mistreatment and neglect at Maryland’s  historic Black hospital – will have their names properly honored and recognized in the Say My Name Memorial.

This was a long overdue act and an important reminder that we must recognize even the darkest parts of our history so that, as First Lady Dawn Moore said, that we will never go back. While I was stuck in DC for votes, I'm grateful my team could join and present a citation in honor of the Marylanders who lived, worked, and lost their lives in the Crownsville State Hospital. Finally, a special thank you to Janice Hayes Williams and the Friends of Crownsville for their unwavering commitment to honoring the lives lost and ensuring every individual is recognized with dignity.

On May 30th, Maryland’s Third District lost one of our youngest members – Hugh Nie – who was just 17 months old. Hugh tragically lost his life to Sudden Unexplained Death in Childhood, but his time was filled with joy and loving memories and his impact in our community is still felt. Hugh’s case is not a one-time occurrence: there are nearly 400 cases of SUDC annually in our country, yet no known cause or form of prevention. We must continue to fight for full funding to lifesaving NIH research so no other family has to experience what the Nie’s endured.

We have another update from the U.S. Naval Academy: the Midshipman who was injured has been released. I'm grateful to the doctors and nurses at the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center, and all those involved in ensuring the safety of our Midshipmen as the Naval Academy resumes operations. It has been a difficult 24 hours for the Annapolis community, and I will continue to be in communication as the investigation unfolds.

A quick update this morning from the U.S. Naval Academy. The Midshipman who was shot in the shoulder last night during the clearing of a building is expected to make a full recovery. Thank you to the first responders, nurses, and doctors for their swift action.

I’m still in constant communication with the Superintendent for any further updates and they are launching an investigation so we can ensure every lesson is learned from yesterday’s incident.

Today, the U.S. Naval Academy went on lockdown after threats against the Academy. There is no active shooter threat, but one Midshipman was injured while Naval Security Forces were clearing a building. Thankfully, they are in stable condition. Please see my full statement below. https://t.co/RjKKMe9soO

Here is what we know: There is currently no active threat at the U.S. Naval Academy. 

I am actively working in coordination with the Navy, our first responders, and the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center. As we wait for further details, I want to extend my gratitude to our first responders.
My team and I are monitoring the situation at the U.S. Naval Academy. Please follow the guidance of local law enforcement during this lockdown.

Nearly 19,000 people in Maryland’s Third Congressional District and 206,000 Marylanders are projected to lose health care because of President Trump's Big Ugly Law. These are not just numbers: these are our friends, neighbors, and family members who will lose coverage, which is why the fight for quality, affordable care here and across the country must continue.

Did you know that one in four of active-duty servicemembers and military spouses report infertility? Yet, TRICARE doesn’t automatically cover IVF and other family planning services. On today’s edition of Sara(hs) Explain It All, I’m joined by @RepSaraJacobs to break down how her amendment to the NDAA is bridging this gap in coverage and the importance of reproductive resources for our military families.

"On a normal day, we value heroism because it is uncommon. On Sept. 11, we valued heroism because it was everywhere." Every year, I re-read this Times article, and each time, I am struck by the stories of courageous individuals and first responders who stepped up to defend their neighbors and our nation in one of our most frightening moments. Today, we honor not only their sacrifice, but our strength as a nation to come together and adapt in the face of that tragedy. Let us never forget.

Today, after careful consideration, I voted against the NDAA. This was not the vote I hoped to take. House Republicans walked away from nine months of bipartisan, good-faith negotiations in committee. I am disappointed this year’s NDAA provided no protections against U.S. troops being used on U.S. civilians and no checks on the President’s powers. See my full statement below:
This is horrific. Political violence is never acceptable. I join my colleagues in praying for Charlie Kirk and his loved ones.

54 days ago, the NDAA passed out of committee with bipartisan support, filled with provisions to better the lives of our servicemembers and improve our military readiness. My colleagues and I worked together for nine months to work on this legislation, which is why I am now pleading with my Republican colleagues to ensure this process remains bipartisan. We should never play politics with our troops and civilian workforce.

Our veterans have sacrificed everything to serve our country – the least we can do is provide them with the quality care they deserve. Yet, the Trump Administration’s VA has proposed returning to a near-total abortion ban – including in cases of rape, incest, or health endangerment – that could prevent more than 2 million veterans from accessing these services. I’ve joined my @DemWomenCaucus colleagues along with @ReproCaucus, House Veterans’ Affairs Democrats, and Senate Veterans’ Affairs Committee Democrats to urge the Trump Administration to withdraw this harmful attack on health care access to our veterans and their family members.

More than 190,000 Marylanders rely on lower premiums from enhanced tax credits to access affordable health care – but these credits will expire at the end of 2025 because of President Trump’s Big Ugly Law. I’m grateful I could stop by our team’s meeting with the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange to discuss how we can work together to ensure all Marylanders have the life-saving care they need.

Our immigrant servicemembers are crucial to military readiness, providing foreign language skills and medical expertise to our military for over a century. Yet the Trump Administration is now arresting, detaining, and deporting non-citizen servicemembers, even as DHS policy clearly states that servicemembers, veterans, and military families have protection from immigration enforcement. I’ve joined over 50 of my colleagues across the House and Senate to demand an investigation into the Trump Administration’s reckless changes to our long-standing policies and uphold our promise to protect those who serve our country.

I sat down with WMAR to discuss how the first-of-its-kind bipartisan MAWS Act would tackle the issue of invasive blue catfish. Now that I’m back in Washington, I’m working with my colleagues to get the MAWS Act to the House floor for a vote, but we can all be part of the solution. Whether it's ordering blue catfish on a menu or processing it in pet food, we can all do our part to save the Bay.

You’ve probably seen it at the grocery store: President Trump’s reckless economic policies are driving up the cost of our essentials. As a member of the Lowering Costs Caucus, I’m committed to fighting for common-sense legislation that makes life more affordable for Maryland families.

Even though President Trump already forced through the largest cut to health care in our nation’s history with the Big Ugly Law, the Administration is once again attacking lifesaving care – this time by adding prior authorization requirements to Medicare. Under this new program, private companies can use artificial intelligence, rather than medical expertise, to conduct private screenings and determine whether patients should receive coverage for dozens of procedures. Delaying and denying care is never the answer.

Today is National Wildlife Day, a time to appreciate and raise awareness about efforts to protect our native wildlife. Maryland is home to thousands of unique plants and animals that contribute to a larger ecosystem, but 176 species of animals are currently listed in Maryland as threatened or endangered – including the American Goshawk that calls western Maryland home. As Vice Ranking Member of the House Natural Resources Committee, I will continue to fight for the protection of our native wildlife and the habitats they rely on to thrive.

Earlier this week, I had the opportunity to welcome and sit down with Lieutenant General Michael Borgschulte, the new Superintendent of @NavalAcademy! Lt. This legislation disregards the expertise of those who know the land best and prevents similar plans from ever being enacted again. The Trump Administration should not be able to mandate how land is used without the input of those who call that land home – that’s why I spoke out in Rules against this change and voted no on these reckless resolutions.

We must continue to educate our communities and provide the necessary crisis response and substance abuse resources that save lives every year.

Other experts at the CDC have spoken out and it’s our turn to speak out and fight for those who have kept us safe for decades.

62 years ago today, nearly 260,000 people joined the historic March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, gathering to protest the nation’s racial inequities and outline their vision for a more just future. This was a march decades in the making. A. Philip Randolph proposed a march for jobs more than 20 years prior, which finally came together in a truly pivotal moment for civil rights in our nation’s history as Martin Luther King Jr. gave his “I Have A Dream” speech. Today and every day, we must work towards making our country one that lives up to that dream of brotherhood and acceptance for all.

Our veterans selflessly sacrificed for our country with the promise that we would take care of them in return. Now, the Trump Administration has proposed a rule that would reinstate the Department of Veterans Affairs’ near-total ban on abortions, including instances of rape or incest.
